6XPZpoW8.question: Explain the term Stable and Unstable Air

options.text: Stable air resists vertical motion. If air in a stable atmosphere is displaced vertically, it will return to its original level. Unstable air does not resist vertical motion. If unstable air is displaced vertically, it may well continue to move - forming vertical air currents.

Stable air resists humidity change. 
Unstable air does not resist humidity change.

Stable air resists horizontal motion. If air in a stable atmosphere is displaced , it will return to its original position. Unstable air does not resist horizontal motion. If unstable air is displaced horizontally, it may well continue to move - forming horizontal air currents, commonly experienced as wind.

Stable air resists temperature change. 
Unstable air does not resist temperature change.

ei5iEcsx.question: Absolute instability in the atmosphere will occur when the environmental lapse rate is

z4EcmzXA.question: A sample of moist but unsaturated air may become saturated by

options.text: lowering the pressure, keeping temperature constant.
the temperature to which moist air must be cooled to become saturated at a given pressure.
the temperature below which the change of state in a given volume of air will result in the absorption of latent heat.
the lowest temperature to which air must be cooled in order to reduce the relative humidity.
the lowest temperature at which evaporation will occur for a given pressure.

uoiNNEUl.question: Which statement concerning volume and temperature of a descending parcel of air is correct?

The volume decreases and the temperature decreases.

options.text: The volume decreases while the temperature increases.
The volume increases while the temperature remains constant.
The volume decreases and the temperature decreases.
